chapter.htmlHeader: Why is identifying and supporting carers important?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• If carers are not identified (by themselves and by health professionals), it is a barrier to them receiving appropriate support and being involved in patient care [RCGP, 2014; Carers Trust, 2018].
    • Many carers do not recognize the term 'carer' in terms of their relationship with, for example, the parent, child, friend, or neighbour that they care for [Carers Trust, 2018]. Some carers do not want to be labelled as carers due to concerns it may not be beneficial, for example affecting job opportunities [RCGP, 2014].
  • GPs are an important first point of contact for encouraging carers to identify themselves and are in a good position to identify and support their patients who are carers due to their long term relationship with patients [Cameron, 2011; RCGP, 2013; Smith, 2014].
    • A larger proportion of carers have had contact with a GP (80â€“90% in the previous 6 months) than with any other health or social care professional [RCGP, 2014].
    • Primary care teams should have an awareness of the problems experienced by carers and be able to support and involve carers in patient care (where appropriate) [RCGP, 2014].
  • Supporting carers involves multidisciplinary input from the health and social care services and the voluntary sector [RCGP, 2014], but the support of primary healthcare professionals can make a significant difference to carers' health and wellbeing [Fox, 2010]. Benefits to the carer of receiving support in general practice include [NHS England and NHS Improvement, 2019]:
    • Improved support with their caring, physical health, and emotional wellbeing needs.
    • Increased confidence in their caring role and feeling that they are providing safer care.
    • Reduced anxiety, depression, and stress.
    • Maintenance of good physical health, for example through improved self-care and being offered health checks.
    • Lower risk of injury because of improved manual handling techniques.
    • Improved awareness of available support services.
    • Feeling enabled to have a life outside the caring role.
    • Reduced risk of carer/family crisis and breakdown.
  • Providing support for the carer means the person being cared for may also be healthier and happier and experience benefits such as improved confidence and trust in their carer, reduced anxiety and feelings of guilt, and reassurance that their carer will continue caring for them [NHS England and NHS Improvement, 2019].
  • Supporting carers can also lead to better care planning; improve the care of people with long term conditions, people receiving palliative care, and elderly and vulnerable people; and reduce unnecessary hospital admissions. Improved carer health and wellbeing may reduce demand on services and prescribing costs [RCGP, 2013; NHS England and NHS Improvement, 2019].
